There is slight difference between having "catalogs": [] and not having this at all. Former suggests that user care about catalog checking, but haven't yet defined any rules (possibly a mistake) and so deny-all, the latter suggests that user don't care about checking the catalog rules and so allow-all).
In other words Optional<List<Rule>> when empty allow-all, when present but list empty deny-all.
WDYT?

Yes this is how most of the rules today treat these today.  An empty array will always result in "no rule matched", so deny.  For no rules provided, the default is typically allow, but there are exceptions.  For every rule set the docs clearly note what happens.
In the later commits, I normalize catalog, schema, and table rules to this.  Instead of using Optionals for these in the code, I replace Optional.empty() with an allow rule, and the other is just an empty list so they get denied.
